Today I met with 2 Dreamers from Laredo. Both of them are high school teachers in Laredo at UISD. 

They shared with me that they have lived their entire lives in South Texas—and have no family nor home to go back to if deported.

(3/4) https://t.co/AYRztO1uFU

They also shared that there are nearly 20,000 educators that identify as Dreamers. If DACA was repealed, the teacher shortage in this country would become even greater.

For our children, and for future generations, I call on my Senate colleagues to find a solution.

(4/4)

But the DACA program has its limitations. The 5th District Court of Appeals will soon hear a case on the future of DACA.

We need permanent, bipartisan legislation so that no Dreamer has to live from expiration date to expiration date. Or court ruling to court ruling.

(2/4)

Today is the 10th anniversary of DACA. This initiative has been instrumental in allowing young immigrants to pursue the American Dream—without fear of deportation.

(1/4)

I will continue to do so. 

Hardworking families in Texas, and across the country, are suffering due to inflation and record high gas prices. I look forward to working with both parties to ensure we focus our energy on jobs and lower prices at the pump. (4/4)

Let me be clear, I fully support the Oil and Gas industry. My track record in Congress demonstrates this. From lifting the ban on crude oil exports to eliminating unnecessary and burdensome regulations for small refiners, I work every day to lower the price at the pump. (3/4)

In fact, the Oil and Gas industry employs over 200,000 hardworking Americans, contributes millions to our economy, and (when championed) keeps the United States energy independent—all of which is vital for our national security. (2/4)
The Biden Administration’s recent letter to refiners does not resolve the issue at hand. What we need is dialogue. We need real solutions. (1/4)
